◆ dig_pit_moves_and_byproducts()

static digging_moves_and_byproducts dig_pit_moves_and_byproducts ( player *  p,
item *  it,
bool  deep,
bool  channel 
)
static
Strength modifies dig rate

Definition at line 2589 of file iuse.cpp.

2591{
2592 // When we dig, we're generally digging out either a deep or shallow pit.
2593 //
2594 // The dimensions are a little hand-wavey... based on our exactly
2595 // as-big-as-they-need-to-be tile sizes, we could assume that the width and height
2596 // are 1 meter each. Our pit could be a square as well, or we could assume it's
2597 // circular and 1 meter in diameter.
2598 //
2599 // Depth is even less rigidly defined, both in terms of "what is a z-level", and in
2600 // terms of how the deep and shallow pits are used in game.
2601 //
2602 // A shallow pit gets used to do things like build an improvised shelter or start
2603 // the foundation for a wall, and is ostensibly a relatively quick effort: a
2604 // survivor might get a crude digging implement (e.g. digging stick) and attempt to
2605 // dig out the start of an improvised shelter, or they might have a proper shovel
2606 // and be digging a foundation footing. Referencing the 2018 IBC
2607 // https://codes.iccsafe.org/content/IRC2018/chapter-4-foundations we can see in
2608 // R403.1.4 the requirement that "exterior footings shall be placed not less than
2609 // 12 inches (305 mm) below the undisturbed ground surface. You'd need even more
2610 // space for the actual footing, but that's close enough. I don't think survivors
2611 // care about building to code, but let's call it 12 inches (0.3048 meters) at the
2612 // maximum for a shallow pit depth.
2613 //
2614 // The deep pit is a little more complicated because it gets used for more complex
2615 // constructions like traps, reinforced concrete wall footings, palisades, wells,
2616 // root cellars, and the like. The depth requirements for those are quite varied,
2617 // but let's just throw some number around to get a feel for it: say at least 2
2618 // meters deep to be an effective pit trap. The USGS maintains
2619 // depth-to-ground-water-level records and provides them at
2620 // https://waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis/current/?type=gw. A cursory review (and
2621 // remembering it's seasonal) shows values in Massachusetts ranging from 122 feet
2622 // and 1 foot, and values between 3 to 9 feet aren't uncommon. Root cellars are
2623 // ideally constructed where the ground temperature has stabilized, below the frost
2624 // line. This depth varies by location, but is somewhere in the 1 to 3 meter range.
2625 //
2626 // With all of that in hand, let's make some estimates.
2627 //
2628 // A shallow pit is a circular pit 1 meter in diameter and 0.3048 meters deep,
2629 // which works out to... ~0.239 m^3. That's so close, let's just call it 0.25 m^3
2630 // or 250 liters.
2631 //
2632 // A deep pit is a rectangular pit 1m x 1m x 2m, or 2 m^3, or 2000 liters.
2633 //
2634 // Now, for how long that takes, things are going to get even more subjective and
2635 // couched in assumptions. Let's assume a single individual, digging in optimally
2636 // diggable soil(rather than something requiring a pickaxe to break the soil or
2637 // requiring saws to remove tree roots), using an appropriate (but manual)
2638 // implement designed for the task (e.g. a shovel). The Canadian Centre for
2639 // Occupational Health and Safety has some interesting recommendations on the rate
2640 // of shoveling, weight of the load, and throw distance at
2641 // https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/ergonomics/shovel.html. Of particular interest
2642 // is the table of "recommended workload for continuous shoveling", which gives a
2643 // weight per minute and a total weight per 15 minutes, as well as a description of
2644 // the conditions. It also discusses the need to take breaks, for example
2645 // alternating 15 minutes of shoveling and 15 minutes of rest in extreme
2646 // conditions. Taking all that into consideration, I'm going to call it 10
2647 // scoops/min * 5 kg/scoop for 15 minutes followed by 15 minutes of rest, or
2648 // effectively 25 kg/min.
2649 //
2650 // Now we need to bring the weights and volumes together. Again, more hand waving
2651 // as the soil composition is going to have a big influence on this. The
2652 // engineering toolbox https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/dirt-mud-densities-d_1727.html
2653 // lists the density of wet and dry versions of many materials. I'm going with the
2654 // assumption that this is moist/wet soil that includes clay, silt, load, as well as
2655 // some rock, so I'll just call it 1700 kg/m^3 on average.
2656 //
2657 // Shallow pit is 0.25 m^3 * 1700 kg/m^3, or 425 kg.
2658 // Deep pit is 2 m^3 * 1700 kg/m^3, or 3400 kg.
2659 //
2660 // We'll do some variables below, but for reference:
2661 // Shallow pit: 425 kg / 25 kg/min = 17 minutes
2662 // Deep pit: 3400 kg / 25 kg/min = 136 minutes
2663 //
2664 // Now, one addendum: we're digging our deep pit in the location that we've already
2665 // dug the shallow pit, so really we should exclude the shallow pit volume from the
2666 // deep when counting the amount of work we need to do.
2667 //
2668 // Adjusted deep pit: ( 3400 kg - 425 kg ) / 25 kg/min = 119 minutes
2669
2670 constexpr double shallow_pit_volume_m3 = 0.25;
2671 constexpr double deep_pit_volume_m3 = 2;
2672 constexpr int dig_rate_kg_min = 25;
2673 constexpr int material_density_kg_m3 = 1700;
2674
2675 // At the time of writing this, a shovel is DIG 3, which is what the numbers are
2676 // balanced around.
2677 constexpr double baseline_dig_quality = 3;
2678
2679 // Get the dig quality of the tool.
2680 const int quality = it->get_quality( qual_DIG );
2681
2682 // Dig quality affects the dig rate linearly relative to baseline dig quality
2683 const double tool_dig_rate = dig_rate_kg_min * quality / baseline_dig_quality;
2684
2685 ///\EFFECT_STR modifies dig rate
2686 // Adjust the dig rate by 2 kg/min per point of strength more/less than 10.
2687 const double player_dig_rate = std::max( 1.0, tool_dig_rate + ( p->str_cur - 10 ) * 2 );
2688
2689 // Figure out the volume of the pit we're digging.
2690 // Subtract the shallow volume from the deep, since we already dug that.
2691 const double volume_m3 = deep ? ( deep_pit_volume_m3 - shallow_pit_volume_m3 ) :
2692 shallow_pit_volume_m3;
2693
2694 // And now determine the moves...
2695 int dig_minutes = volume_m3 * material_density_kg_m3 / player_dig_rate;
2696 int moves = to_moves<int>( time_duration::from_minutes( dig_minutes ) );
2697
2698 ter_id result_terrain;
2699 if( channel ) {
2700 result_terrain = ter_id( "t_water_moving_sh" );
2701 } else {
2702 result_terrain = deep ? ter_id( "t_pit" ) : ter_id( "t_pit_shallow" );
2703 }
2704
2705 return { moves, static_cast<int>( volume_m3 / 0.05 ), "digging_soil_loam_50L", result_terrain };
2706}
Character::str_cur
int str_cur
